Award.AwardTitle: An Optimal Transport Based Multiscale Method for Inverse Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the advent of computing powers, the application of inverse problem theory has extended to almost all fields of science and engineering that use mathematical methods. Examples of inverse problems can be found in various fields within medical imaging, several areas of geophysics including earthquake source inversion and hydrocarbons exploration and many machine learning applications in data science. The proposed study will connect optimal transport, a classical analysis subject, with many widely used methods in data-driven problems. Results of this research will offer better understandings of existing numerical methods and promote the development of the new techniques for solving inverse problems with high accuracy and fast convergence. The wide range of applications will also increase partnerships and collaboration between academia and industry. Students will be offered many opportunities of joining this research in translating attractive theoretical properties of optimal transport onto various applications in modern science and engineering.

The proposed research analyzes the intrinsic multiscale features in optimal transport-based seismic inversion to build robust algorithms for solving general nonlinear large-scale inverse problems. The focus is on designing objective functions in constrained local optimization. A standard approach of measuring the least-squares mismatch between model predictions and data is to use frequency marching and weighting methods in which different frequencies are treated separately; first the low-frequency errors are eliminated followed by high-frequency errors. This particular ordering based on the multiscale inversion scheme addresses two of the biggest challenges in inversion by mitigating problems with local minima in gradient-based optimization and accelerating convergence. The PI's recent work has introduced a framework for seismic inverse problems using the Wasserstein distance as the objective function. Using the theory of optimal transport, the PI proved that this metric offers a convex optimization landscape and the PI's numerical experiments demonstrate the convergence to global minimizers for cases where the least-squares norm has difficulties. The proposed research will investigate the connections between optimal transport-based inversion with existing frequency marching and weighting methods to extend the optimal transport techniques to nonlinear inverse problems beyond seismology. In particular, the PI will formulate optimal transport-based inversion for quantitative photoacoustic tomography (QPAT) and cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM). Methods in this work will be developed using existing frameworks of iterative methods and dynamical systems for convergence analysis. Theoretical results from this research will shed light on the relationship between data fitting (residual reduction) and model fitting (solution error) in various data-driven inverse problems and iterative methods. Computational algorithms will be developed for inversion in seismic imaging, medical imaging, and biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Everyday life is full of inverse problems: problems or situations that can be addressed by collecting clues and using backward reasoning to narrow down a specific sequence of events that can solve a mystery. Recently, we have shown that a different mathematical theory--optimal transport--also becomes extremely useful in tackling many challenging inverse problems. 


We analyzed and applied the quadratic Wasserstein metric from the optimal transport theory as a loss function for nonlinear seismic inversion, which we treated as a large-scale nonconvex optimization problem. We proved the convexity of this particular metric and its insensitivity to noise, tackling the long-standing challenges of the traditional method. Despite the computational challenges of solving optimal transport problems and the large-scale nature of seismic wave propagation, the oil industry shortly adopted the method for field data inversion.


Motivated by the fantastic effects of changing the loss function, we focused on a class of Sobolev norms for its spectral bias towards the different frequencies. Our analysis is novel as the theorems offer error bounds and prove the spectral properties of the methodology. The benefits of using the Sobolev norms are more prominent in inverse problems where we established resolution analysis and demonstrated the improved stability with respect to high-frequency data perturbations. Our detailed mathematical analysis also explored the naturally embedded frequency-weighting feature of the quadratic Wasserstein metric and set up connections with long-standing frequency-sweeping techniques in wave-based inverse problems in both the deterministic and Bayesian frameworks.


Many multiscale-type algorithms first perform optimization using the low-frequency data for better stability, and higher-frequency data are utilized later to improve the resolution. Recent applications include cryo-electron microscopy and electrical impedance tomography, beyond waveform-based inverse problems with time-domain data. However, a crucial question to be addressed in methods based on frequency bias is when to perform the frequency transition. On the other hand, the spectral biasing inside optimal transport and the related Wasserstein metric is natural as no manual adjustment is needed. We have explored the non-asymptotic spectrum biasing of the quadratic Wasserstein metric that facilitates spectral multiscale methods for a broader class of optimization tasks, including imaging, deep neural networks training, and tackling the related generalization issues.


Typically, noises in the data hamper the accuracy of the solution and lead to overfitting but can aid in other challenging situations. Adding randomness prevents iterates in optimization problems from stagnation but makes it challenging to stabilize around the truth. The dilemma is hardly addressed despite the intensive research activities centered around the stochastic gradient descent methods. We developed stochastic algorithms equipped with a multiscale nature that can achieve almost-sure convergence to the global minimizer by establishing mathematical theories that balance enough randomness to avoid iterates from clumping around local minima and the final decrease of randomness to stop the iterates from escaping the global basin of attraction. We provided rigorous theories that guide the practice in choosing adaptive step size and the dynamic power of randomness.


There has been a paradigm shift and appreciation for the implicit regularization effects when choosing the loss function in data-fitting problems formulated for inverse problems. The project has resulted in solid mathematical analysis on how one can harness the power of weighted norms to improve the convergence speed of iterative optimization algorithms and improve the stability of inverse problems and improve the optimization landscape. We have extended the original application of just waveform inversion to dynamical system parameter identification, image processing, and machine learning.


Though the original motivation of the grant project was to solve inverse problems and other constrained optimization problems from optimal control and optimal design and machine learning, the use of the weighted norm also extends to the research community on iterative methods. Changing the norm for residuals in iterative methods is the corresponding analog of changing the loss function in optimization problems. The preconditioning effect is evident particularly for speeding up fixed-point iterations. Another cross-discipline impact is that when dealing with inverse problems related to the kinetic theory, changing the loss function may involve the interchange between the Eulerian description and the Lagrangian description for the same physical system. This brings many insights into mitigating the ill-posedness of inverse problems from the kinetic theory. 


To date, the project has produced eleven peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in preparation and under development. The project has also allowed the PI to mentor fourteen students (one high school, ten undergraduate, and three graduate students) on research problems related to the project, while six of the students are identified as women. The majority of the students have decided to pursue a career in related STEM areas. It is a gratifying experience for the PI to open the door of scientific research to these young scholars.
